comments.author: esther
comments.content:
The banchan looks so delicious! :) So cool that you're writing a book!!!

Do you use mung bean sprouts or soy bean sprouts? I was under the impression that it was soy sprouts, but maybe not. I love to add a hint of gochugaru for a spicy kick and color! YUM!

comments.author: Jeanette
comments.content: Yum, I love banchan - it's one of my favorite parts of a Korean meal!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks, Esther! There are banchan made from both of those types of sprouts. I believe the mung bean sprout version is known as sookju namul and the soy bean sprout version is kongnamul muchim - but someone please correct me if that isn't right... I'm definitely no expert on Korean food, just an appreciating amateur!

comments.author: Cooking Contests
comments.content:
I just brought in a batch of zucchini from our garden, and I think i just found the recipe to put them to use! What other dishes would you suggest to go alongside?
~Nancy Lewis~

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks, Nancy! Here are some ideas for dishes these banchan go well with: mandu (Korean potstickers), tofu & kimchi bowl, vegetarian japchae.

comments.author: Ivy Manning
comments.content: Banchan! It's the best part of going to my Korean friend Cathie's house for dinner. She's always got those out, but when I ask her how she makes them, she does that shrug of the shoulders "it's easy, I don't have a recipe" kind of thing. Thanks for posting these!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I love that there are 100s of them and you can feel free to improvise... maybe we should start a banchan meme: post one and tag a friend :)

comments.author: marla@familyfreshcooking.com
comments.content: I adore small little sides like this, especially with these large flavors.

comments.author: weirdcombos
comments.content:
Banchans rock! 
we've been eating lots of Korean food lately. Funny thing is that the main focus in Korean food is meat but to me the side dishes have always been the star in the meal. I am going to try your recipe with a couple of dishes using Kabocha squash and white sweet potato. Toasted sesame oil and gochugang go so well with these two veggies.
Cheers,
Heguiberto

comments.author: Mary
comments.content: I gotta say, all of these awesome veggie versions of Korean dishes have me flipping out over here.  Now I've got a long list of new stuff to try to get my inner Asian on!

comments.author: Jenn
comments.content: Made the zucchini banchan last night to go with a Korean stir-fried pork belly recipe - it was delicious and easy and fast. Thanks!
